title: lockdown diy tattoos stick and poke trend and even kaia gerbers had a go
story: The stick and poke trend, which uses a sharp pointed needle and black ink to create a DIY tattoo, was already on the rise before coronavirus hit.But now the £ kits, widely available online, are selling like hotcakes and Instagram pages are being flooded with pictures of homemade inkings.Even celebrities are having a go, with model Kaia Gerber showing off her quarantine body art, including an angel design on her back and a heart on her shoulder.The method - said to be more painful than a normal tattoo - involves dipping a sterile needle into the ink then piercing the skin numerous times to produce an outlined design.It can then be shaded using dferent sized needle, or left as an outline.Although the kits bought online have sterilised needles, doctors have warned against using any unsterilised equipment or sharing with others as it can lead to skin infections and diseases such as Hepatitis C.Here are some of the home artists who have been having a go.Charlie Wright, from Nottingham, has taken matters into her own hands and created some devilish designs during the pandemic.The demon drawing on her thigh was the th tattoo she had completed in isolation, before she added the words The Devil In I.Charlie - who calls herself TheDevilsBabex on Instagram - also self-drew the butterflies and the Im Not Okay message on her left thigh.This reddit user was proud of her artwork depicting a bird breaking free from a chain, a butterfly, a heart and a rose.She captioned the picture, My legs, all handpoked, all by me.One reddit poster proved such a fan of soft drinks he decided to ink a carton on his leg while in lockdown.With the amount each session stings, a wasp is probably an apt mot for a stick and poke tattoo.Reddit user motherofallthings took two hours to complete this design and revealed this was her fourth attempt at home inking.Louis Tomlinson is well known for his multiple tattoos and his fans are taking inspiration from him for their home pokes.Twitter user Jana posted a picture of her smiley face tattoo, a replica of the One Direction stars wrist tatt.She wrote: Soooo I just did my first handpoke tattoo ever and IM SUPER PROUD OF IT. Ofc its smiley face. Because Louis Tomlinson is really important person in my le and..i just need to know that Im not alone. So..here we go!One newcomer to stick and poke is staying abreast of the trend by inking this female form on her friends bottom.She wrote: I’m slowly getting better! Also tried tattooing with a tattoo pen today! Tbh I like the feeling of stick and poke much better! I feel more connected to the person.A dog lover with a sausage dog named Loaf used his home poke skills to create a permanent tribute, which he called Bad Loaf.A little bit of nature is a must when living in lockdown and reddit user Kinaglos took her inspiration from the poppy fields of Calornia.This barbed wire design is based on a logo a reference to anime Cowboy Bebop, and was the home design of Twitter user Myled.He wrote: I did a tattoo and it made me happy.If you let your friends loose on your back, you had better trust them with your le.This design was posted on reddit with the caption, Healed trippy face I did on a friend.Dont stare at it too long - it will freak you out.While the online kits may be safe, doctors warn that any unsterilized needle could cause painful skin infections, Hepatitis C and HIV.In a recent NHS video, Dr Rob Hicks said: “The potential health risks that come from having a tattoo that people ought to be considering beforehand obviously is the issue of contaminated equipment, equipment that is contaminated with infections, so Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C and HIV.“These are the major things that anybody considering having a tattoo should think about beforehand and be aware off.”Sepsis.org recently advised against home tattoo kits, adding: “The inks have been associated with infections and allergic reactions and the agency is concerned that tattoos done at home may not follow all infection-prevention strategies.”It may be proving tricky to find love in lockdown but one Simpsons fan has found a novel way of approaching the problem.After inking this tattoo he posted online with the caption, Big simple, tryna get we. Doh!A cat lover gave reddit readers paws for though with this cute little kitty design.He wrote: Done yesterday! All hand poked.Whether this home artist was offering advice to angry trolls or a keen cook, she could also have been talking to her own skin.After hours working on that design it must have burned.For a first effort, this fern design is in pretty good shape.The reditter it belongs to posted it with the message: First poke,  hours old. An experiment to see how light and how close I can go... might heal to a blob.It cant be easy to tattoo a heart design as tiny as this with a stick and poke kit.But at least when the tattoo parlour opens, it will be easy to colour in.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ibuprofen improve coronavirus survival rate 80 preventing serious cases
story: IBUPROFEN could be the key to treating severe cases of coronavirus, doctors hope.The cheap painkiller could help improve survival rates by up to  per cent, and reduce the need for patients to be treated in intensive care.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt comes after controversy early on during the pandemic, over fears the anti-inflammatory may make Covid- worse.French health minister Olivier Veran suggested the drug could worsen infections, and prompted Sir Patrick Vallance, Englands chief scientic adviser, to tell Brits to take paracetamol instead. The NHS also removed ibuprofen as a suggested treatment for mild cases. But, a subsequent study suggested the drug did not worsen or improve patients conditions.Now, a team of scientists in London are starting a new clinical trial to seethe anti-inflammatory could in fact help speed up the recovery in some patients by reducing serious side effects.Its hoped a special formulation of the drug - not the standard painkiller - could lead to shorter hospital stays and fewer people ending up in intensive care units .Animal studies have shown that the treatment can increase survival rates by  per cent.Prof Mitul Mehta, whos leading the trial at Kings College London, told PA: This is very promising, but of course it is an animal study, so we want to translate that really compelling result into humans.Its a trial for patients with Covid- disease to seegiving them an anti-inflammatory drug - a specic form of ibuprofen - will reduce the respiratory problems they have.Prof Mehta stressed that the trial was for patients already in hospital, not those with mild or suspected Covid-.Volunteers will be selected from patients who are in hospital, but that are not so ill they need intensive care.Prof Mehta said: If we can reduce their symptoms at that stage we have a number of benefits. We could reduce the amount of time someone spends in hospital - they might recover quicker and go home, thats obviously a fantastic outcome.We also might be reduce the degree of respiratory distress so that it can be managed in the hospital setting, without needing to go to ICU, and thats a fantastic outcome as well.Theoretically, this treatment, given at this time, should be beneficial.But, of course, this is based on animal studies. Its based on case reports, we need to do a trial to show that the evidence actually matches what we expect to happen.The Liberate trial is being carried out at KCL as well as Guys and St Thomass NHS Foundation Trust, along with the pharmaceutical organisation, the SEEK Group.Prof Richard Beale, a consultant in intensive care medicine, at Guys and St Thomass, said: As a new illness, there are limited treatment options for patients with Covid-.The clinical trial will assess whether this unique formulation of an established drug benefits patients.Half of the patients taking part will be given standard care, while the other half will receive standard care as well as the special ibuprofen formulation.Prof Matthew Hotopf, director of the NIHR Maudsley Biomedical Research Centre, said: This highly innovative therapeutic approach seeks to rapidly advance a potentially important new treatment.If successful, the global public health value of this trial would be immense given the low cost and availability of this medicine.Earlier this year, at the start of the pandemic, there was some controversy over the use of ibuprofen after a French health minister advised against using it.Scientists in the UK launched a review and the NHS removed the drug as a recommended treatment for mild cases. But the findings showed ibuprofen does not make Covid infections better or worse.The Commission on Human Medicines expert working group concluded: There is currently insufficient evidence to establish a link between use of ibuprofen and susceptibility to contracting Covid- or the worsening of symptoms. To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: china delayed coronavirus data saved thousands weeks who
story: CHINA delayed the release of coronavirus data that could have saved lives for two weeks, a leaked WHO report has claimed. The news comes after months of speculation about attempts by the countrys regime to cover up the extent of the outbreak in the beginning.The WHO publicly praised Chinas cooperation at the time, but the plaudits were reportedly only part of an attempt to abstract more information from the government.A report compiled by the World Health Organisation describes how three government labs succeeded in sequencing the viruss genome over a week before it was published on January , the Associated Press reported.Sequencing was an essential step towards understanding the behaviour of the virus and developing a vaccine, and was first accomplished by the Wuhan Institute of Virology on January .Interviews and internal documents reportedly suggested that the delay releasing the data was caused by tight controls on information as well as competition within the Chinese healthcare system.Even after the data had been released, China reportedly delayed for another two weeks as the WHO tried to obtain from them detailed data on patients and the number of coronavirus infections.Maria Van Kerkhove, a US epidemiologist who is now the WHOs technical lead in the fight against coronavirus, said in one meeting: Were going on very minimal information.Its clearly not enough for you to do proper planning.Speaking to the Associated Press, Ali Mokdad, a professor at the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, said it was obvious that we could have saved more livesswter action had been taken.The WHO publicly praised Chinas cooperation at the time, but the plaudits were reportedly only part of an attempt to abstract more information from the government.In another meeting, Dr Gauden Galea, the WHOs most senior official in China, said: Were currently at the stage where yes, theyre giving it to us  minutes before it appears on [state media].In a speech at the Wealth Health Assembly last month, Chinese President Xi Jinping claimed China had always provided information to the WHO in a most timely fashion.He also pledged billion over the next two years to help fight the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Todays report comes after officials in Wuhan, where the outbreak began late last year, said that no new cases of the virus had been found after a round of testing that reached .million of the citys million people.It also follows earlier reports that China threatened the WHO into delaying warnings about Covid- while it stockpiled medical supplies.

story: -year-old senator Martha Lucia Micher started getting changed during a May  meeting with members of the National Regeneration Movement political party, the Bank of Mexico, and journalists.Screenshots from the meeting originally meant to discuss the impact of the coronavirus pandemic were leaked by an unknown attendee.Sen. Micher apologised for the incident after it did the rounds on social media and she was mercilessly trolled by creeps and perverts.The senator took a strong stance against the bullying and came out swinging, saying she is proud of her body and refuses to be objectied.She said: “I am Malu Micher, and I am not ashamed to have shown part of my intimacy by accident, because it is exactly the notion that a woman is ‘just her body’ that has allowed and fomented the objectication of women against which I have always fought.“I am a woman of  years of age who has breastfed four children, three of whom are today professional and responsible men, and I feel proud of my body for having nourished them.“I am a woman who has fought for the left for almost  years and who has occupied ious public roles in my fervent commitment for the defence of human rights, I am a woman who is not ashamed of her body, I love it and I take care of it.”Many of her colleagues and fellow politicians have come out to show solidarity with the senator.Fellow senator Ricardo Monreal Avila wrote: “In view of the attacks against her, a product of a mishap during a virtual meeting, we endorse our fellowship. Morals and integrity will always be stronger than infamy and assaults.”Another senator, Maria Elena Morena posted: “The rubbish stinks in the senate and on social media. Our political and party dferences should have limits.”Fellow party member Martha Tagle wrote: “I will investigate and sanction those responsible for taking and leaking these photos. The violence to which you were subjected cannot go unpunished.”According to local media, parliament has stated that they will take legal action against those who publish photos of the incident on social media.Sen. Micher is not the first person to suffer a Zoom blunder.A recent Zoom that included Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro also hosted a naked man, and a Spanish news anchor was caught cheating on his girlfriend when a naked woman walked across the room during a video call on live TV.

story: BRITS could face the end of the “cheap curry night”the two-metre social distancing rule is imposed on Indian restaurants, it is claimed.And the fear is that the pandemic could mean that between a third and a half of them “close for good”.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMany such restaurants are small and rely on tables closely packed to offer competitively priced meals.Bosses of all restaurants and pubs want the Government to half the distance to one metreAnother worry is that customers will stay away as two groups — older people and the Asian community — have been particularly hit by Covid-.Shahab Uddin, who owns Streetly Balti in Sutton Coldfield, West Mids, contributed to a report by Aston University on concerns within the sector.He said all restaurants and pubs are under pressure but the threat to curry houses, run mostly by those with a Bangladeshi background, is greater.Takings from takeaways are a fraction of what they would earn from customers dining in.Mr Uddin said: “We’re going to have to put up prices by a £ per meal to make a go of thingsand when we reopen.Sonny Ahmed, with restaurants in Bradford and Portsmouth, “wouldn’t be surprised per cent close for good.”To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: ALL shops could still reopen in  days time eventhe coronavirus alert state is not lowered, No has insisted.Downing Street revealed the PM’s determination to press on with his roadmap to unlock Britain.It came as it emerged the nation’s four chief medical officers have now wrestled control of setting the new Covid- alert rate.Tension is mounting between ministers and government scientists after some warned Boris Johnson is unlocking too fast.The four top medics for England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are still refusing to move the alert status done from  to  – which was previously a condition for lockdown restrictions to ease.Boris stated in his original plan that the newly formed Joint Biosecurity Centre would decide which of the five levels the country was at.But the PM’s spokesman confirmed: In terms of the setting of the alert level, it is ultimately for the chief medical officers, informed by data collated and analysed by the JBC.“The JBC’sis to provide analysis and advice.”The spokesman also insisted that the decision on reopening all non-essential retail is “not dependent” on the alert state descending down to level .Under the PMs roadmap timetable, they will be given the green light to open their doors again on June .Critics also pointed out that the average number of daily deaths has now stropped falling and is instead flatlining at the  mark.After the usual weekend reporting lull, the death toll was back up to .To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: two metre social distancing economy
story: IN parks and on pavements up and down the land you cannot escape the numerous signs telling us to stand at least two metres apart.It has become the new normal — stand back, give people space, don’t spread the virus. And Britain has been very good at it.But as we slowly move out of lockdown with thoughts of shopping, seeing our friends and family, and a cool drink in a pub garden, how effective this two-metre rule actually is has become a new national obsession.Many are starting to ask: Do we really need to keep a two-metre gap  Could it in fact be ONE metre  It may sound trivial, a metre is still too far to hug, kiss, even to shake hands with friends and loved ones.But for many businesses which rely on allowing people to gather more closely — theatres, restaurants, pubs, to name but a few — cutting the official social distance in half could be the dference between keeping afloat or going under.The official advice of the World Health Organization is that one metre is sufficient, a belief shared by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.The Danes changed their position three weeks ago to one metre and most of the European countries’ public health officials advise one metre in certain circumstances.Now a new study by the WHO has found that while a two-metre distance reduced the risk of the virus being passed on to . per cent, a one-metre gap only increased the chance of transmission to . per cent.So a small risk either way, but enough to justy potentially endangering some of the industries we both enjoy and, for many thousands, rely upon for work. I have been asking for a couple of months how that distance was established, yet its origins are very obscure.It seems to go back to research on the distance between beds in the old-fashioned Nightingale wards in the s. It has become a folklore of infection control and public health, until people have started asking questions about it today.Experiments about the distance droplets travel have been conducted under such articial conditions that they are not applicable to everyday lives.Laboratory air is articially still, whereas air is not still, even when you are sitting in a room with all the windows and doors closed. Air flow breaks up the particles from a sneeze or a cough and they tend to fall pretty quickly on to your clothes or face.The serious risk of infection is when you get up to half a metre away from somebody with Covid- who sneezes or coughs.But the dference between one metre and two metres is the dference between a very small risk and a very tiny risk.To the economy, the dference is a radical one. Shting from two metres to one metre would allow us to get back to something close to business as usual. If you imagine a two-metre circle drawn around any inidual, that takes up  and a half square metres.When you come down to a one-metre safe zone, it is only . square metres. So you could get four times as many people into any given space. With the two-metre rule,  per cent of pubs and bars say it wouldn’t be economically viable to reopen. With four times as many customers, only small pubs would face dficulties.The current approach doesn’t grasp that town centres are leisure destinations and that people won’t go outit is an unpleasant experience. Shoppers want to have a coffee, lunch, try on clothes, it is a social activity with their friends.I believe that cinemas are safe to reopen and that perhaps we might be able to allow some fans back into football stadiums to cheer on their teams again.In a typical cinema, where seating is tiered and there is air conditioning,you do happen to be coughing out, the thermal heat from the bodies should rise it up out into the air conditioning system.Allowing fans to attend football matches again would be a challenge, because of the congestion going into the stadium.They would have to carefully plan entrance and exit times and leave every other seat vacant unless there is a family group, so you would probably be playing in front of a stadium which is  per cent full.I may be part of a faction that favours one metre, but the consensus is that the risk of transmission outside is very low.So joggers don’t have to go into the road to avoid getting too close to someone  on the pavement — because their slipstream will mean the droplets will probably stick to them anyway.The best way to reduce the risk of the virus spreading is a good standard of hygiene, sanitising your hands at the end of a journey and after eating.If you are involved in a lot of customer interactions, such as supermarket checkouts, Perspex barriers are helpful.The Government has taken so much flak on easing lockdown restrictions that they seem to be reluctant to get into a fight on this one. But we need to remember that interrupting the transmission of the virus is not about rules and their enforcement.It is about assessing the risk at each inidual venue, because sticking to two metres in all cases poses a risk to our economic health.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nightclub coronavirus ibiza coronavirus wayne lineker
story: IBIZA club boss Wayne Lineker has revealed he has had to shut down his dancefloor to fend off coronavirus.Lineker revealed a raft of strict new measures to protect partygoers from Covid- as nightclubs search for ways to adapt amid the pandemic.Wayne - brother of footballer Gary Lineker - unveiled new measures for his venues while speaking on This Morning.It comes as the Spanish nightle industry has drawn up a new raft of measures to allow clubs to open post-coronavirus lockdown.The party boss boasted he has made his venues - such as the famous Linekers bar in Ibiza - safe for staff and holidaymakers as Spain looks to kick-start tourism.Measures such as shutting down the dancefloor, two metre distances between sunbeds, hand sanitiser on the tables, staff wearing masks and disinfectant mists will be in place.He said: Theres not going to be a dancefloor this year which is a shame but current times make sure thats not a possibility.We just want to be very safe for the clients.Wayne added they also have a strong security team to try and make sure guests keep social distance even while drunk.They will be very polite and very well mannered in the way they address the people, he said.Spain is expected to reopen its borders to international tourists from July - but nightclubs around the world are looking for new ways to reopen.Wayne is confident that Linekers can reopen on July  to welcome the seasons first guests.Meanwhile, Spains National Federation of Leisure and Entertainment Businesses have drawn up a new raft of measures for venues to crackdown on coronavirus.Plans recommend all clubbers will have to wear facemasks and will have to wash their hands as they enter and leave.Customers will also not be able to mix drinks, and they will only be served with disposable straws.Seating areas will also be reserved, while markings on the floor will help people keep their social distance.Drinks will have to be ordered on an app to avoid clusters of people at busy bars.And while Wayne has closed off his dancefloor, the new guidelines say you can have one - but as long as social distancing is enforced.The beloved nightspots in destinations such as Ibiza and Magaluf will be able to reopen again once Spain begins phase three of its lockdown easing plan.Other nightclub measures could include QR codes being scanned on the door to keep track of who goes into the venue.South Korea is rolling out this scheme that also includes churches, gyms, concert halls and restaurants to help trace coronavirus cases.The persons information is logged by the government and held for four weeks before being deleted.It will allow anyone who has potentially come in contact with a coronavirus case to get notied so they can tested.It is unclear when nightclubs and pubs will begin to fully reopen in Britain, but pressure is growing to review the two metre rule.A new study has suggested just one metre may be almost as effective at combating the spread of coronavirus.Meanwhile, there is hope for summer holidays to party hotspots in Spain as the UK considers easing plans for a -day quarantine.It is hoped the two week legally-mandated isolation could be scrapped by the end of June.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keeping pubs afloat sun says
story: WE would put up with a lot to get back to the pub. We’re just not sure we’ll ­recognise the experience under the ­Government’s plans for them.Perspex screens protecting staff who will barely interact with punters ­anyway. Drinks ordered by app, then wordlessly collected from the bar.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesStrict limits on numbers, with the dubious two-metre distancing rigidly observed. Costly new ventilation systems supposedly dispersing the virus.Hardly a cosy and inviting prospect. Butit keeps our pubs afloat, great. We dearly hope it will last only a few weeks.The signs are looking up. Oxford Professor Carl Heneghan reckons our death rate will be at “normal” levels next week, with zero Covid deaths by July.Another eminent professor says there is no ­evidence a second wave will hit us.Even a holiday looks a little more likely. EasyJet will fly to  per cent of its destinations by August.Yet half of Britain remains hooked on the lockdown, unwilling to venture out, to narrow the two-metre rule . . . terried of even the gentlest easing of rules.And many are better off than before. In April we paid off a record £.billion of personal debt and tripled our monthly savings to £.billion. That’s thanks to generous furlough payments, mortgage holidays and saved daily expenses.Far too many think this surreal situation is sustainable. It is not. A huge crash is coming when the bailouts end.The faster weto normality, the less horric its impact will be. WHEN is quarantine not quarantine  When you can still go out — even on the bus.This contradictory fudge is, incredibly, what the Government has come up with, caught between those wanting to lock visitors up for a fortnight and those, like The Sun, who believe that would wreck tourism, our economy and vast numbers of jobs.Quarantining already looks bonkers at this stage. This half-measure is a joke:Restrictive enough to deter most travellers, but not enough to prevent badly infected arrivals from passing Covid on. And farcical enough to further erode trust in the Government.IT should not take George Floyd’s appalling murder and the ensuing protests to remind the world that black lives matter.That sentiment was also why it was vital for Public Health England to find out exactly why BAME people have a higher risk of dying from Covid — and to recommend counter-measures.Why didn’t it  The PHE report just restates what we knew. It failed even to allow for obesity or a victim’s job — both crucial factors. title: urban fox snout shorter scavenge bins
story: The animal is known for its cunning but its head and brain is becoming smaller as it adapts to le among humans, researchers say.And the males have become metrosexual — shrinking to almost the same size as the vixens.An international team compared  skulls of red foxes from London and the countryside.Researcher Dr Kevin Parsons, of the University of Glasgow, said: “We saw urban foxes had a smaller brain size capacity but also a dferent snout shape that would help them forage within urban habitats.“There was also less of a dference between males and females in urban foxes.”He says the ergence of city dwellers from their country cousins also helps explain the evolution of dogs from wolves to our domesticated companions.The number of red foxes in urban areas of England has soared from , to , in  years.They are often brazen around humans, even approaching them for food.Dr Parsons added: “Urban red foxes are becoming more similar to domesticated dogs as they adapt to their city environment.”The similar size of the sexes brings them closer to many domesticated animals.Researcher Dr Andrew Kitchener, from National Museums Scotland, said many of the changes would have been similar in the initial phases of domestication for our pets such as dogs and cats.He added: “So, adapting to le around humans actually primes some animals for domestication.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: school shutdown poor kids 16 months behind
story: THE shutdown of schools could leave poor kids  months behind better-off classmates, a study found.By the end of primary school, they are on average . months behind richer pupils.This gap could widen to as much as  monthsschools stay shut until September, the Education Endowment Foundation and Sutton Trust found.The study said it was “highly unlikely” a short-term catch-up strategy could make up the time.EEF’s Prof Becky Francis said poor kids were “particularly impacted” by not being in school.The report states: “The projections suggest that school closures will widen the attainment gap between disadvantaged children and their peers, likely reversing progress made to narrow the gap since .It adds: “It is highly likely that the gap will have widened when pupilsto school, eventhe strongest possible mitigatory steps are put in place.“There is a risk that high levels of absence after schools formally reopen poses a particular risk for disadvantaged pupils.”Ministers faced down militant trade unions to order the phased reopening of primary schools from Monday –  weeks after they were shut down.But a string of mainly northern councils are refusing to open their schools until later in the month.All primary school kids are expected to spend some time in class before the summer holidays next month. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: family boy devastated blown inflatable wind
story: Little Ben Duffy was on a dinghy while his family played nearby, but a gust of wind pushed the boat out into deeper water, their local priest has said.By the time the inflatable was caught up with, the boy was missing and a frantic search was sparked.Tragically, it was called off in the early hours of Tuesday morning after his body was found by rescuers.Partry parish priest Fr John Kenny told The Irish Sun: “It’s a safe bathing area on the lake but the little boy was on a little dinghy and the wind took the craft out further than where it would have been safe for him to be.“And it drted onto the lake further than anybody would go bathing.“When they caught up with the dinghy he wasn’t in it anymore so we don’t know what happened - expect he must have fallen out or jumped out.”Do you know the family involved in the tragedy  Get in touch on tips@the-sun or Fr Kenny added: “The family were using the little dinghy as part of the fun and games in the shallow safe part of the lake but he went a bit too far with it and the wind brought it further.“Wherever it went to, it appearshe would have stayed on it, he might have been safer but he must have fallen out for some reason.“It’s a tight-knit community and the boy went to the local school and some of his classmates and neighbours would have been swimming in the local vicinity swimming in the same area where it happened.“I know the family well. They’re very active in the parish through the school mostly but they’re also very parish involved and anything to do with local sports or organisations.“Ben was a lovely little boy. He was one of the youngest in his class. He was bright-eyed, literally bright-eyed and cheerful.Always full of le but particularly he was a very smiley little boy.“The whole community feels for the loss of Ben for his family and we convey our sympathies and we want them to all know we’re here for them even though it’s dficult particularly with all the restrictions. It makes it even more poignant.”The tragic accident happened near the Tourmakeady side of the Lough Mask in Co Mayo at around :pm on Monday.The Irish Sun understands Ben, who was a Junior Infants student at Scoil NaisiuntaThuar Mhic Eadaigh, was one of five children to parents Alan and Tracey - it is believed he had three brothers and one sister.Fr Kenny added: “The family are obviously devastated and the community are in shock. What was a normal summer’s day turned into a tragedy in a matter of minutes.“I happened to be in the vicinity when it happened running an outdoor charity raffle and when we saw the helicopters coming we called everything off and some of us made our way to the shoreline to be with the family.“Local people had begun the search already. Everyone on the shoreline felt so helpless and sad for the family.”The family who have been described as “popular” were heavily involved in the community in GAA and football and mum Tracey is believed to teach dance.Obviously, what was a very enjoyable day no doubt for families turned into disaster with the loss of a young five-year-old boy.“With Covid, everything was tied down with no school, no nothing over the last few months and the Bank Holiday weekend comes and there was a little bit of freedom.“I suppose people felt like they could go down to the lake because they live very close to it. To think it turned into such a disaster is unbelievable.The Fine Gael councillor also praised all the people who were involved in the search effort for Ben.A Garda spokesman said: “Gardai in Castlebar assisted by Coast Guard, Civil Defence, Lough Mask Water Rescue and local ers can confirm that the search operation for the five-year-old boy has been stood down as his body was recovered from Lough Mask.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rubbish urine bbq booze litter britain beaches
story: SHOCKING pictures show piles of rubbish, bottles of urine and used BBQs left on Britains beaches during the sunshine.People making daytrips after spending weeks at home have been slammed for not cleaning up after themselves and leaving the beauty spots in a much worse state compared to just weeks ago. Thousands of Brits have flocked to the coast during weeks of sunny weather, and have left plenty of litter.Just a few weeks ago these spots were mostly people and litter-free as the country remained in stricter lockdown, but relaxation of the rules has seen people swarm beaches.Families and friends were pictured sitting close together at ious UK beauty spots this weekend - making it impossible to keep social distances and keep the areas clean and tidy in many cases.A foul outcome of these day trips has been bottles of urine left behind, as public toilets are closed as the coronavirus pandemic continues.The phenomenon, known as “fly peeing”, is causing beauty spots to turn into public toilets, and the bottles to pile up along roads and beaches.Small coastal villages with limited facilities, such as Weybourne in Norfolk, have been covered in bottles of urine and nappies.Lyndon Swt, the parish council chairman, said: “The car park is inundated and we have zero toilet facilities so the beaches and hedgerows are filling with toilet paper.”Becky Jarrett hit out on social media, saying: “They had to open a load of loos on the Norfolk coast for the bank holiday weekend due to people leaving bottles of wee and heaps of poo and dirty nappies all over the beaches here the week before.“Disgusting idiots.”On the other side of the country, a care worker from Burnham-on-sea, Somerset, reported people urinating in public against her garden fence.Others said boozy Brits caught short had even defecated in private gardens.Crowds on beaches and clfs at Durdle Door over the weekend showed a shocking disregard for the area, a conservation charity said.Lucy Culkin, chief executive of the The Jurassic Coast Trust, said it had received hundreds of messages from members of the public since the weekend.She said these highlighted the appalling volume of litter on beaches, including human waste, sanitary items, and surgical masks and gloves, as well as disposable barbecues.The lack of respect for our coastline shown by some has deeply saddened our local communities and visitors alike, she said.It was clear to see that some had all but forgotten the guidelines of social distancing or welfare for themselves and others, or indeed any respect for the natural environment they were visiting.And calls have been made to ban people from Skegness beach after pictures of litter strewn across the popular attraction were posted online.Papers, beer cans and disposable barbecues were among the items left behind by visitors across several parts of the resort.The images were shared online by the RNLI East of England, which pleaded with people to take their rubbish home.The organisation wrote on Facebook: If youre making the most of this weather at the beach... please take your litter with you!There are plenty of bins to choose from.The revelations sparked outrage, with many calling on the Government to reintroduce the ban on people visiting beaches.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit fishing deal calais blockades
story: Officials from the EU and the UK are trying to hash out a deal on fisheries - one of the biggest sticking points - as they continue talks this week.EU countries want to continue to be able to fish in British waters and dont want to have their current quotas cut.But the UK has vowed to take back control of its waters and give priority to British fisherman.But any new agreement on fisheries would deprive France and other European countries of a signicant part of their fishing hauls which could spark fury and blockades, according to The TimesNational Federation of Fishermens Organisation Barrie Deas said: As night follows day there will be blockades, theyve done it for much less in the past.The entrance to the port at Calais is only a few hundred metres wide and it would only take a couple of trawlers to block traffic.Britain has proposed annual fishing quotas are based on zonal attachment which reflects where fish live - rolling back the current system where European boats land over six times more fish from Britains coastal waters than British Fisherman.The PMs chief Brexit negotiation David Frost and his team are to hold a fourth round of talks this week.The EU has signalled it is willing to find a compromise on quotas, but France has privately warned other European government that blockades would begin within  hours of any deal that cuts the catches of French fisherman.Chaos at Calais would threaten  per cent of the UKs trade in goods - roughly £ billion a year.Mr Deas said any agreement would move away from fishing rights and quotas set out in the Common Fisheries Policy and instead be based on the geographical location of fish.French fisherman catch  per cent of the cod caught in he Channel and  per cent of haddock in the Irish sea.The current sizes of these catches could be slashed under new rules.Mr Deas said: The way to achieve [a deal] is a recognition that . . . quota shares will have to change to more closely reflect resources that are in UK waters.“I think there will be a reaction in France by the fishermen. I think that’s just the nature of the beast.”Downing Street said it was not willing to compromise Britains interest.A spokesman for Downing Street said: We have always been clear there is no question of splitting the dference on fish.We aren’t compromising because our position is fundamental to an independent country.Mr Deas said any attempt by the EU to block a free-trade deals to gain ground on fishing would be a nuclear option that would damage both sides.He added:would be extremely damaging to the EU as well as to the UK, that’s why I think there will be a compromise.

title: dad mcdonalds camped drive thru
story: Rik Dove, , pitched his tent outside the fast food joint in Sutton-in-Ashfield, Notts., on Sunday night hoping hed be the first customer on Monday morning.The dad-of-five is seen smiling in a tiny pink tent in the drive-thru lane, with a childs plastic car in front of him as his vehicle.But Riks hopes were crushed when he was told he had the date the wrong and the restaurant doesnt actually open until Thursday.McDonalds plans to reopen  of its drive-thrus between from June  to June  - meaning Rik has to wait a little longer to get his burger.Rik said: I got moved on not long after I got there. title: boris promises 24 hours test results
story: BORIS Johnson has said all test results will be ed within  hours by the end of June. The PM announced the move at PMQs today after being criticised for not getting a working test and trace system up by his own June  deadline.Mr Johnson said today: We already do have  per cent of tests turned around within  hours of the tests conducted at around  testing centres theyre all done within  hours.I can undertake to him [Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer] now to get all tests turned around in  hours by the end of June.The PM tried to ward off criticism from Sir Keir who claimed he had title: madeleine mccann investigation latest theories
story: Despite a £million police probe, her whereabouts - or whether shes dead or alive - remains a mystery.Madeleine vanished  years ago on May , , when her family, from Leicestershire, were holidaying in Praia da Luz, in the Algarve, Portugal.Parents Gerry and Kate left their three children – including toddler twins Sean and Amelie – sleeping in their apartment while they dined at a tapas bar -  metres away.When Kate ed to check on the kids at around pm that evening, she discovered that Madeleine was not in her bed and was missing.In September of that year, Gerry and Kate, both doctors, were sensationally named as ‘arguidos’ by Portuguese police.The following summer the McCanns were cleared by investigators in Portugal who declared they had exhausted all avenues in the case.Madeleine would have turned  on on May , .In April , UK cops released a computer generated image of Madeleine showing what she would look like aged nine.However, parents have said new images of Madeleines age progression are bogus. Kate and Gerry are warning the new fake images were neither commissioned nor endorsed by them or Scotland Yard’s Operation Grange team.A number of potential leads have emerged since the little girl vanished, but none amounted to anything and no arrests have ever been made.In May , witness Jane Tanner said Gerry had played tennis with a man wrongly identied as her abductor on the day she went missing.She said she spent up to half an hour watching Gerry McCann and Dr Julian Totman, , play on May , .Less than three hours later, she saw a man carrying a child in pyjamas near the McCanns’ apartment in Praia da Luz.But she did not recognise Dr Totman and cops pursued the lead for four years, despite the GP saying it was probably him.There have been more than investigative avenues that are of great interest to both the UK and Portuguese teams pursuing the case.Met cops believe she was stolen by child traffickers or sex fiends, or during a burglary gone that you Daddy  and he replied Yes in a foreign accent, author Anthony Summers said in the Netflix doc.Detectives have discovered a creep carried out nearly  attacks within a -mile radius of the holiday apartment in Praia da Luz where Madeleine vanished from  years ago.He crept into Algarve properties rented by families and many victims were British.And a judicial source is reported to have confirmed the unnamed man was definitely in Portugal at the time the three-year-old suddenly disappeared.And the insider also alleged he was known to local cops and had previously been investigated on suspicion of involvement in paedophile cases.A chilling reconstruction features in the final episode of Netflixs eight-part documentary The Disappearance Of Madeleine McCann.A German paedophile Martin Ney, , emerged as a key suspect in May .He was jailed for le in  for abducting and murdering three children and sexually abusing dozens more.It is believed he was in Portugal when Madeleine went missing.Goncalo Amaral, the Portuguese cop who first led the hunt for Madeleine, revealed that police were probing a “German paedophile who is in prison”.Ney was working for an evangelical church on a project for the homeless in Portugal when Madeleine disappeared, its claimed.Ney also looks like a photofit of a man, who was seen acting suspiciously before Madeleine vanished from her Portuguese holiday apartment  years ago.Funding for the search was due to expire in October .But on September , , it was confirmed investigators have received £, to keep the probe alive until March .Then more funding - said to be around £, - was granted in March .The extra cash for Operation Grange is being used to investigate signicant leads, which Assistant Commissioner Mark Rowley described as very worthwhile.Kate and and Gerry are “extremely thankful to both the Home Office and Scotland Yard for the continued funding,” their spokesman Clarence Mitchell said.The Home Office announced it was ploughing more money into Operation Grange, the official investigation, at the latest request of Met Police.In June  it was confirmed that the politan Police were asking the Home Office for more funding to continue the work of Operation Grange.Scotland Yards investigation has been ongoing since .During that time the number of detectives working on the case was cut from  to four in .The Home Office said in June  that the previous year saw it provide “£, of funding to the MPS. “The cost of Operation Grange to date is £.m.”Those still involved with the investigation are Andrea Parker is lead head teacher of three London primary schools, Bonneville, Jessop and Stockwell. She explains how a “bubbles” system will work: “There will be a maximum of  children in class. In our reception classes, we’ve got around eight children in each bubble. And it’s not just about the size of the bubble, it’s about the dynamics of the bubble as well. Children are people. “We’re going to really use more of our outdoor space for reception in particular, where they will be working in smaller groups. We’ll be removing all soft furnishings, and with things like the climbing frames only one bubble can use it at any one time and then it will be cleaned down before another bubble can use it.”  Staggering the drop-off and pick-up times is important to keep children and their carers safe – and schools are putting a new system into place. “We’ve got lines painted at the entrance a two-metre distance from the boundary of the school for drop-off,” says Ms Parker. “The bubble lead will be there for  minutes, and will then take her group through a marked route to their room. And then there’ll be  minutes after that for parents to leave the streets and to wait for any late children that might come here afterwards.

Luke Hall raised the half-baked idea in a letter to council chiefs, urging them to consider all options for supporting homeless people in the pandemic.More than , rough sleepers were offered emergency accommodation as coronavirus unfolded, including in hotels, as part of a scheme called aposEveryone Inapos.Mr Hall has now given English councils until June  to produce a next steps plan of where people should be housed. He wrote to town hall chief executives on May : In terms of move-on accommodation, all options need to be considered. We ask that you seek to encourage people, where appropriate and possible, toto friends and family. The letter went on to advise councils to find as many sustainable move-on options for people as possible. This could include working with housing associations to supply more homes, supporting people to move into private rents, or short-term accommodation to stop people ing to the streets. But Shadow Housing Secretary Thangam Debbonaire slammed the letter - which came after the government pledged to end rough sleeping in the wake of Covid-. She said: This half-baked suggestion shows that this Government is already rowing back from that promise. “These comments smack of incompetence.  Luke Hall has shown a woeful lack of understanding about the complex reasons why so many people sleep rough in this country. If rough sleepers were able toto their friends and family, they would not be sleeping rough. They need somewhere safe to live and the support to make a go of it. “The Government should be working with councils to fulfil its commitment to end rough sleeping, not washing of its hands of the responsibility to house the homeless. Coronavirus rules make it illegal in England to stay overnight away from the place where you are living. A Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government spokesman insisted people wouldto friends or family only where appropriate and possible. He added: Our new rough sleeping taskforce has one overriding objective: to ensure as many people as possible who have been brought in off the streets in this pandemic do notto sleeping rough.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAs parents across the country endure their third month in lockdown, many will have had to deal with toddlers throwing screaming tantrums. So they will have had sympathy for Keir Starmer today having to deal with a similarly irrational outburst of anger and frustration. On the very day Boris Johnson vowed to “take control”, the Prime Minister stood up in the Commons and promptly lost it. Like a lb gorilla asked to do long ision without a pen and paper, Mr Johnson grunted, stomped and slammed his fist on the despatch box. Detective Chief Inspector Starmer spent another episode of CSI Westminster applying gentle scrutiny to the government’s handling of the Coronavirus crisis. “I really do not see the point,” Johnson growled, “of his endless attacks on public trust and confidence. The suggestion that the Johnson should have a word with his friend Donald about the horrendous, heavy handed policing of Black Lives Matter protests was met with more grumping. “I perfectly understand people’s right to protest what took place,” he said, like a man who had never spent hundreds of thousands of pounds on illegal anti-protest water cannons. Questioned on his plan to force MPs toen masse to Parliament - a building singularly unsuited to social distancing - was snootily dismissed. MPs should expect to come back to “do their jobs” - which now includes spending hours queuing up in a snaking round the creaky building’s grounds. It’s just like Disneyland, only the mice running across the canteen floor don’t wear trousers and white gloves. Meanwhile, scores of disabled, elderly and shielded Parliamentarians - not to mention thousands of members of the public who’ve been working from home - will question whether the PM thinks they’ve been sitting with their feet up since March.  Surely due for his trenchcoat and cigar any day now, Starmer asked why the PM’s promised “world beating” test and trace system was still missing key elements. He asked why lockdown was being eased before the PM’s own alert level said it should. And he asked why Johnson had failed to reply to a letter from Starmer offering support with plans to re-open schools. But answers there came none and Johnson tossed his Captain Calamari out of the pram, thumping his fists and accusing Starmer of undermining the public’s confidence in him.

title: dad set up camp mcdonalds
story: NewsDad set up camp in McDonalds drive-thru in desperate bid to be first - four days earlyRik Dove was so determined to be the first customer at the restuarant, he set up camp at the drive-thru on Sunday evening, only to be told by a member of the public it doesnt open until ThursdayShareCommentsBySophie NorrisJamie Hawkins:,  JUN NewsRik preparing for a night outside his local McDonalds " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA fast food-fanatic who camped outside a McDonaldaposs drive-thru waiting for it to reopen left empty handed after he was four days early. Dad-of-five Rik Dove pitched his tent at the Kings Mill Road East restaurant in Sutton-in-Ashfield, Nottinghamshire, on Sunday night hoping to be first in line the following morning. A hilarious photo shows him grinning eagerly in a tiny childrenaposs tent in the drive thru lane - with a plastic Little Tikes car for children in front of him as his aposvehicleapos. But before the -year-old could properly bed down for the night, a member of the public told him he had the wrong date - as the restaurant doesnapost open again until Thursday. McDonaldaposs recently announced it would reopen its  drive thrus from June  to June , meaning Rik had no chance of bagging a burger. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, click here Rik claimed he planned to beat the traffic by setting up camp with a LOL Surprise pink tent and Little Tikes car - seemingly unaware of McDonaldaposs rules that only vehicles with an engine can use drive thrus. Its website states: McDonaldaposs drive thru is for people in motor vehicles only - bicycles are not permitted on our drive thru due to the health and safety policies we have in place.  Despite the official policy, Rik is set to try again tonight and hopes to be first in line for Big Mac on Thursday morning. Rik, from Sutton-in-Ashfield, said: I got moved on not long after I got there. My local McDonaldaposs doesnapost open until the th. A member of the public who possibly had a family member who worked there told me. I was gutted. Iaposm a big lad and needed a Big Mac in my le. I thought it [opened on Monday] so Iaposve not managed to get one as of yet. I was going to get my kids some nuggets but only a box of twenty as thataposs all I would fit in the car. It was kind of cramped due to the tent and chair in the back. Iaposll be back on Wednesday to try again. On social media, Rikaposs sister Lisa [Dove] said: Just dropped our Tubbys off at McDonaldaposs. First in the drive thru ready for opening. Manaposs got needs. Return of the Fat Mac. Her post attracted more than , shares and reactions from entertained Facebook users who joked Rik was in for a cold night in his tiny tent - not realising he was actually tucked up in his own bed after discovering his error.

The body of schoolboy Adam Kay was found in the River Irwell on Tuesday following a huge search operation. He was last seen in the water near Clton Country Park in Manchester on June .  The park was evacuated and a huge search operation got underway at around .pm. Witnesses told Manchester Evening News they saw at least  response vehicles and a helicopter at the scene. His body was found by underwater search teams a short while later. The tragic incident has since sparked an outpouring of grief for the teenager, who was a pupil at Harper Green School in Bolton.  Kellie Thygesen said: “I really wish this wasn’t true. Sleep well your dad will keep you safe now. We will all miss you. Love you my baby nephew.” Jessica Kay said: “love u million ur with dad now... “...heartbroken isnapost the word I shouldnapost be saying good bye to u.”  Leon Murphy Hayes said: “Rest in peace Adam. Thoughts are with you and your family.” A number of teachers from Harper Green School have since paid tribute to Adam, describing him as a “charismatic inidual” who “always had a smile on his face”. Headteacher, Stephen Gribbon, said: “Adam only joined our school this year but he very soon became popular due to his kind nature. “Adam always had a smile on his face and his boundless energy was infectious. In school Adam was always laughing and joking with his friends and had time for everyone. “Adam’s innate ability to befriend anyone that had the pleasure to meet him meant that people liked being around him and the loss of such a young and charismatic inidual will affect so many people. “My thoughts are with Adam’s family and friends and I offer the support of all the Harper Green community at this incredibly sad time.” Deputy Headteacher, Sally Heppenstall, said: “Even though he had only been at Harper Green School a short period of time, Adam very quickly became a valued and well liked member of our school community.  “I will remember him for his infectious laugh. He would spend breaks and lunch-times on the yard and in the year team with his close group of friends laughing and joking around. “His laugh was infectious. He was a loyal friend whose tragic passing will affect so many. My thoughts are with his family and friends.

story: NewsMans legs compared to Drumstick sweets after sharing photos of horric sunburnLewis Reed headed for a picnic with his mum on Brighton beach to make the most of the hot weather, and regretted his decision not to wear sun cream for months afterwardsShareCommentsByLuke MatthewsAudience Writer:,  JUN NewsLewis now sticks to sitting in the shade " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPeople have been left wincing at the photos shared by a man who showed off the results of not wearing sun cream after sitting on the beach for just an hour and a half.Lewis Reed had headed to Brighton beach with his mum to make the most of the hot weather and skipped the opportunity to apply sun protection as he aposwasnapost a fan of the sticky formulaapos.The -year-old said he didnapost feel any burning sensations as he relaxed on the beach, where he sat for about  minutes in the sunshine. Any confidence that the decision to ditch sun cream had been a successful one quickly vanished as Lewis was left mortied when his legs turned bright red and began to blister moments later.  With sizzling temperatures ing and summer round the corner, Lewis shared his previous experience on Twitter, writing: When people ask me why I want to sit in the shade I show them these photos.He was forced to treat the horric burns with aloe vera gel for weeks until the redness subsided, but the tan lines stuck around for a lot longer. He said: I went for a picnic with my mum on the beach and lost track of time, we were only there for an hour and a half.  I didn’t notice I was burning at the time I was hot but couldn’t feel myself burning. I didn’t wear any sunscreen, I hate to feel sticky so I never wear it. I was quite scared, as my whole legs were bright red and started to peel and blister. My family were shocked and terried but they found it hilarious. I was in tremendous amounts of pain for days after. I used aloe vera on it for weeks after, it eventually went down but the tan lines were visible for months.

title: schools wales reopen june 29
story: NewsAll schools in Wales to reopen on June  for four weeks before summer holidaysWelsh education minister Kirsty Williams said the four-week term ending would give pupils, staff and parents time to prepare for the new normal when the new academic year starts in SeptemberShareCommentsByAdam Hale:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsA staggeredto school will begin in Wales on June  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAll schools in Wales will reopen on June  for four weeks before the summer holidays, it has been confirmed. The countryaposs education minster, Kirsty Williams, said a four-week term ending on July  would give pupils, staff and parents time to prepare for a new normal when the next academic year begins in September. Today she said a phased approach would see staggered starts, lessons, and breaks for dferent year groups, with a third of pupils at most in school at any time. Under the plans, teachers will also be given priority for antibody testing. My announcement today gives schools three-and-a-half weeks to continue preparing for the next phase, she said. We will use the last weeks of the summer term to make sure pupils, staff and parents are prepared - mentally, emotionally and practically - for the new normal in September. June  means there will have been one full month of test, trace and protect, which will continue to expand. I can also announce that teachers will be a priority group in our new antibody-testing programme. As we continue to keep Wales safe, this approach will be critical.The evolving science suggests that warm weather and sunlight gives us the best opportunity to ensure more time in school.Waiting until September would mean almost half a year without schooling. That would be to the detriment to the wellbeing, learning progress and mental health of our young people. Ms Williams said theplan was the best practical option and met the five principles she previously said would have to be met before acould be considered. She also said allowing pupils toto the classroom was the best way to meet the needs of vulnerable and disadvantaged children.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A strict lockdown would be needed in the UK for the next year to control coronavirus, save lives and prevent UK hospitals from becoming overwhelmed, a new study has suggested.Researchers said extreme measures are likely required to prevent very large numbers of deaths and intensive care units from filling up. The measures could include social distancing, school closures, shielding by the elderly and vulnerable, and self-isolating at home, the study said. It comes as the Governement gradually eases lockdown restrictions in England after  weeks amid fresh signs that more Britons are ignoring social distancing rules.to get the Mirror’s daily coronavirus briefing email at mirror email -after the press conference every evening. Confirmed cases and deaths have been trending downwards since late April, but there are fears that the UK will suffer a devastating second wave as the lockdown is relaxed.The study, carried out by the Centre for the Mathematical Modelling of Infectious Diseases Covid- working group and published in -X fulltext utm_campaigntlcoronavirusutm_content" target"_blank" rel"nofollow"The Lancet medical journal, analysed the potential impact of dferent measures to control the spread of Covid-.The group includes John Edmunds, a member of the Governmentaposs Sage committee and a professor of infectious disease modelling at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. It looked at four main control measures, or base interventions, that have already been imposed in the UK - school closures, social distancing, the shielding of the elderly and vulnerable, and self-isolation when people come down with symptoms. Using ious models, the researchers tried to predict the number of new cases over time, patients requiring intensive care treatment and deaths, and how the measures would influence the rate of infection, or R rate. With no control measures, the study projected  million cases and , deaths by December .  The toughest lockdown scenario resulted in a projected , cases and , deaths, according to the study. The authors wrote: Intensive interventions with lockdown periods would need to be in place for a large proportion of the coming year to prevent healthcare demand exceeding availability. The characteristics of SARS-CoV- mean that extreme measures are probably required to bring the epidemic under control and to prevent very large numbers of deaths and an excess of demand on hospital beds, especially those in ICUs. As of this week, more than , people have died from coronavirus, according to official figures based on death certicates mentioning Covid-.Britain has the worst death toll in Europe and the second highest total in the world, behind only the US. The four base interventions were each likely to reduce the rate of infection, but not enough to prevent hospital intensive care units from being overwhelmed.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThousands of demonstrators chanted no justice, no peace as they gathered in Londonaposs Hyde Park to take part in a Black Lives Matter protest. Star Wars actor John Boyega gave an emotional speech - describing demonstrators as a physical representation of our support for George Floyd. The event was organised following the shocking killing of Mr Floyd, who died after white Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin was filmed pressing down on his neck with his knee. The footage has sparked outrage around the world. Todayaposs protest in Lonon moved from Hyde Park as crowds walked towards Downing Street via Victoria Station.At Victoria, demonstrators hung a sign reading justice for Belly Mujinga, including members of the rail workeraposs family. Belly Mujinga was a rail worker who died from coronavirus after being spat at while on duty at the London station by a man who said he had COVID-. Many held banners saying I canapost breathe - the words Mr Floyd repeatedly told the officer shortly before he passed out. Others said the UK is not innocent and demanded justice in tackling racism.After leaving Hyde Park, hundreds headed south as they blocked off Park Lane Road, stopping traffic and at least  double decker buses.Many drivers stuck in traffic sounded their horns in time to chants from the crowd.As part of the protests today, actor Boyega referenced two other black Americans who controversially died in the US and the racist UK murder of Stephen Lawrence, as he told demonstrators: We are a physical representation of our support for George Floyd.  We are a physical representation of our support for Sandra Bland. We are a physical representation of our support for Trayvon Martin. We are a physical representation of our support for Stephen Lawrence. He added: Iaposm speaking to you from my heart. Look, I donapost knowIaposm going to have a career after this, but f*** that.  Today is about innocent people who were halfway through their process, we donapost know what George Floyd could have achieved, we donapost know what Sandra Bland could have achieved, but today weaposre going to make sure that wonapost be an alien thought to our young ones. US President Donald Trump has come under fire for threatening to bring in the military to tackle disorder after curfews were imposed in cities across the country following eight days of protests. Today Boris Johnson was pressed on why he had stayed silent - before he finally voiced his condemnation. Protesters were urged by campaigners behind the rally to stick to social distancing rules. Organiser Naomi Smith, , told the Evening Standard: “It’s important that we do this in London to show solidarity.  We will keep to the social distance rules and this is a peaceful demonstration.” Todayaposs rally comes after a protest march on Sunday in Central London, with gatherings also held in cities across the UK, including Liverpool and Manchester. Earlier today the Prime Minister was grilled about his response to the crisis, amid calls for him to condemn Trumpaposs heavy handed approach. In answer to a question from Labour leader Keir Starmer, Mr Johnson replied: I think what happened in the United States was appalling, it was inexcusable, we all saw it on our screens and I perfectly understand peopleaposs right to protest what took place. Though obviously I also believe that protest should take place in a lawful and reasonable way.  Labour leader Keir Starmer said: I am surprised the Prime Minister hasnapost said anything about this yet. I do hope that next time he speaks to President Trump he will convey to him the UKaposs abhorrence about his response to the events. Chief constables from across the UK have issued an extraordinary joint statement condemning the killing.They said they stand alongside all those across the globe who are appalled and horried after Mr Floyd, , died after being restrained. In a statement, the chief constables, the chair of the National Police Chiefsapos Council, the chief executive of the College of Policing and the president of the Police Superintendentsapos Association said: We stand alongside all those across the globe who are appalled and horried by the way George Floyd lost his le.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe partner of a New Zealand woman who died at just  years of age says she drank two litres of Coca Cola a day. Amy Louise Thorpe, from the South Island city of Invercargill, was addicted to the popular fizzy drink, he told a coroner holding an inquest into her death. The mum-of-three died of an epileptic seizure two years ago. Her consumption of the caffeine-laden beverages were considered as potential factors in the hearing probing her death, reports Stuff. The inquest was told the young woman drank two litres of Coke almost every day, and additionally consumed up to a litre of energy drinks daily too. She was found unresponsive in her Invercargill home on December, , . Findings delivered this week say her soft drink consumption may have contributed to her death. Samples of Ms Thorpeaposs blood and urine analysed after her death reportedly uncovered the presence of caffeine and nicotine. A report released by Coroner David Robinson said she smoked around  gramsof tobacco a week. He noted she had a history of epilepsy and was up to date with her medication, but her most recent seizure had been just three days before her death. Ms Thorpe also suffered from depression, anxiety and sleep apnoea, the report said. Mr Robinsonaposs report said she had a raised body-mass index and a history of gestational diabetes.  Ms Thorpeaposs partner described her as being addicted to Coca-Cola. He told police his partner consumed advising police consumed on average two litres a day, along with around ml to litre of Mother branded energy drink a day. A friend, Madonna Bresolini-Meikle​ provided a statement to police. According to Stuff she said: Amy had more energy drinks a day than people have coffee. She enjoyed her V drinks and Coke. The coroner considering her death referenced research linking high caffeine energy drinks to seizures in adults. A neurologist consulted for the inquest added that research on the phenomenon was ided and described the data as lacking. He said some studies suggesting caffeine intake could increase seizure susceptibility, while others found it could potentially protect against them. However caffeine was also shown to inhibit anti-seizure drugs commonly used to manage epilepsy, such as Topiramate, he added.  Dr Graeme Hammond-Tooke​ said: In the case of Ms Thorpe, I think it is possible that excessive caffeine contributed to poor seizure control. While modest intake of caffeine contained in drinks is not likely to affect seizure control, large amounts probably do increase seizures, and may have other adverse effects on health. The coroner encouraged the case to be publicised, saying people with epilepsy and doctors advising them should should be made aware of potential consequences from using too much caffeine. A tribute page for Ms Thorpe described her as a aposmuch-lovedapos mum-of-three and partner. Her case bore similarities to another death in the same city in . A coroner found Invercargill mum-of-eight Natasha Harrisapos death was also linked to excessive Coke consumption after she drank up to eight litres a day for several years before she died. At the time, Coca Cola denied its product played any proven role in the -year-old womanaposs death.  Meanwhile, the UK is banning the sale of energy drinks to children following a campaign backed by teachers unions and stars including celebrity chef and sugar-tax advocate Jamie Oliver.

Paola Moreno turned heads by opting to appear on camera with her head resting on a towel and her eyes hidden behind shades. Mrs Moreno, deputy mayoress and finance councillor in the Costa del Sol resort of Torrox east of Malaga, has been accused of damaging the local authority’s image by the rival left-wing PSOE party. The right-wing politician is said to have earned €for attending the Zoom regional local authority meeting.The meeting on Monday coincided with an easing of coronavirus restrictions in the resort of Torrox, which meant locals and expats couldto the beach to sunbathe and enjoy their first dip in the sea for two and a half months.For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, click here PSOE general secretary Juan Manuel Cortes accused the brunette of showing a “lack of respect.” He told local media: “Paola Moreno’s attitude should be questioned not only by the mayor but also within the association of municipalities. “We regard what she did as irresponsible and a lack of respect.”  But Mrs Moreno has hit back by saying she was at the beach because of a promise she had made to her children after they had been banned for so long - and insisted she was able to focus  per cent on what was being said because her husband took charge of the kids. She told respected local paper Opinion de Malaga: “At .pm I went to the beach with my children because I wanted to reward them for their good behaviour during the lockdown. “There was a meeting at pm and from the sun lounger where I was, I wanted to fulfil my political responsibilities and I was concentrating all the time. “When the meeting was about to begin I told my husband to look after the kids and he went with them to the shoreline so I could focus on what was being said.”
